  • Creation, providence, and every contingent detail of history.
  • Election and reprobation.
  • The permission and ordination of sinful acts, without God’s sinfulness.

Key points:

  • The decree is not reactive or discursive. It is identical with God’s simple eternal knowledge and will; its “order” is logical, not temporal.
  • Election is unconditional. God’s decree to save particular persons is not grounded in foreseen faith or works, but in his good pleasure in Christ.
  • Reprobation is likewise decreed, but asymmetrically: God positively and efficaciously brings about faith and holiness in the elect, while in the reprobate he withholds saving grace and orders their sin to just judgment without infusing evil.

The decree provides the metaphysical ground for the certainty of salvation, the efficacy of grace, and the assurance that redemptive history is not contingent upon creaturely indeterminacy.

Concurrence and secondary causality

To avoid collapsing the decree into occasionalism, Reformed thought insists on robust secondary causes under God’s universal concurrence.

  • General concurrence: In every action of every creature, God is the primary cause, giving existence, power, and efficacy to the secondary cause at the moment of its operation.
  • Mode-specific concurrence: God concurs with each cause according to its nature. Free acts are elicited as genuinely rational-voluntary acts; physical processes operate by natural necessity; etc.
  • No competition of causes: Divine and creaturely causation are not on the same ontological scale. God’s causation is transcendent and undergirds, rather than displaces, created agency.

This framework allows:

  • Sinful acts to be genuinely the acts of the creature, springing from its own disordered will, while still falling within the scope of God’s providential ordering.
  • Saving faith and repentance to be acts truly performed by the believer, yet grounded in an antecedent, effectual divine operation.

Compatibilist freedom and the author-of-sin question

Reformed theology is compatibilist rather than libertarian.

  • Freedom defined: A human act is free when it proceeds from the agent’s own intellect and will, without external coercion and in accordance with the agent’s strongest present inclination.
  • Moral inability: Fallen humans possess natural faculties of choice, but their moral disposition is corrupt; they cannot will spiritual good apart from regenerating grace. Inability is ethical, not metaphysical.

Within this frame:

  • God’s decree and providential concurrence determine what free agents will in fact do.
  • Agents are nonetheless responsible because they act voluntarily from their own character, not under physical compulsion.

The author-of-sin objection is answered along several axes:

  • Efficient vs. deficient cause: Sin, as privation of due rectitude, has no positive efficient cause. God efficaciously concurs with the act as an act; the disorder in the act arises from the creature’s defect.
  • Holy willing vs. evil willing: God wills the existence of sinful acts under a good aspect (as occasions to glorify justice, mercy, etc.); he does not will the moral evil as evil. The same event is related to God and the sinner under different respects.
  • Asymmetry in grace and hardening: God effectually produces new holy dispositions in the elect. With respect to sin and hardening, he judges, withdraws restraints, and hands over to existing corruption, but does not create sinfulness.

Thus God ordains that sin infallibly occurs, yet the sinner alone is culpable; God is first cause of the act’s existence, not of its privation of righteousness.

Irresistible grace

Within this metaphysical frame, irresistible (better: effectual) grace describes the Spirit’s work in bringing the elect to faith.

  • Regeneration precedes and grounds faith: The Spirit sovereignly renews the heart, removing the heart of stone and giving a heart of flesh. This renovation is monergistic.
  • Efficacious calling: In the elect, the external call of the gospel is inwardly accompanied by the Spirit’s illumination and heart-changing power, infallibly resulting in faith and repentance.
  • Freedom preserved, not destroyed: The new heart freely embraces Christ. Grace is “irresistible” not as a violent force against the will, but as a transformative act that changes what the will delights in and therefore chooses.

On compatibilist terms, once the heart is renewed, the person’s “strongest inclination” is toward Christ; the elect cannot finally resist saving grace because God has altered the very spring of their willing.

Sola fide as instrumental cause

Given the decree and effectual grace, Reformed theology nuances sola fide in causal terms.

  • Meritorious cause: Christ’s obedience and satisfaction alone.
  • Efficient cause: God’s gracious, justifying verdict.
  • Instrumental cause: Faith alone, as receiving and resting on Christ.
  • No causal gap: Faith itself is decreed, granted, and sustained by God, yet genuinely elicited from the human subject as secondary cause.

Important features:

  • Faith justifies not by its quality or meritorious value, but as the God-ordained instrument uniting the sinner to Christ.
  • Because decree and concurrence extend to the act of faith, there is no wedge between divine sovereignty and justification by faith alone; the same decree that appoints the end (salvation) appoints the means (preaching, regeneration, faith).
  • Assurance is grounded in the immutability of God’s decree and Christ’s finished work, with faith functioning as the means by which the believer participates in what God has eternally purposed.

Thus the compatibilist framework underwrites sola fide: the believing response is simultaneously God’s effectual gift and the creature’s responsible act, serving as the exclusive instrument by which Christ’s righteousness is received.

Summary

In classic Reformed theology, the eternal decree and universal concurrence of God entail a compatibilist account of freedom in which God infallibly brings about saving faith by irresistible grace, without becoming the author of sin, while faith alone remains the Spirit-given instrumental cause by which the sinner is justified in Christ.

top_exam_questions.question: You describe the covenant of redemption as an intra-trinitarian agreement. In light of divine simplicity and one will in God, explain precisely what ‘agreement’ can and cannot mean ad intra, and how you relate the pactum salutis to the one, simple, eternal decree.
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal background

Classic Reformed theology wants to affirm simultaneously:

- **Divine simplicity and one will in God**: God is not composed; he does not have parts, and the divine essence is identical with God's attributes and act of willing. In God there is one simple act of knowledge and one simple act of will.
- **Real personal distinctions**: The Father, Son, and Spirit are really distinct hypostases, distinguished by eternal relations of origin (begetting, being begotten, spiration), not by three centers of consciousness or three separate volitional faculties.
- **A single eternal decree**: God’s decree is one, eternal, simple act by which he freely and wisely orders all that comes to pass, including the entire economy of salvation.

Any account of the **pactum salutis** must be formulated within these constraints.

## What “agreement” cannot mean ad intra

The language of intra-trinitarian “agreement” is analogical and cannot be pressed in a univocal or creaturely way. Specifically, it cannot mean:

- **Negotiation between divergent interests or wills**  
  There are not three separate volitional centers that might disagree and then converge. To posit such is to deny simplicity and to reintroduce tritheism. There is numerically one divine will, proper to the one essence, subsisting in three persons.

- **Temporal sequence of deliberation**  
  Agreement in human agents presupposes discursus: proposal, consideration, assent. In God there is no before and after, no deliberative process, no successive mental states. The decree is eternal, simple, and non-discursive.

- **A contract between independent parties**  
  Covenants among creatures presuppose distinct moral subjects who could have done otherwise and bind themselves by promise. The divine persons are not independent agents who might or might not collaborate. Their operations ad extra are indivisible.

If “agreement” were taken in any of these senses, it would imply either composition in God, change in God, or a multiplicity of wills—each of which contradicts the classical doctrine of God.

## What “agreement” can mean ad intra

Within the constraints of simplicity and one will, “agreement” can function as a reverent, accommodated way of expressing several things.

- **Hypostatic appropriation of the one decree**  
  The one, simple, eternal decree includes the whole order of salvation. Within that decree, the works ad extra are executed according to the taxis of the persons:
  
    - The Father decrees to elect and send.
    - The Son decrees (as person) to assume flesh and redeem the elect.
    - The Spirit decrees to apply and consummate redemption.

  This is not three distinct decrees or three volitions, but one decree, subsisting and “modulated” according to each person’s personal property. Agreement, in this sense, is the harmonious personal manner in which each hypostasis wills and executes the same undivided plan.

- **Trinitarian taxis in willing, not plurality of wills**  
  Because will is a property of nature, the one divine will is the will of the Father, of the Son, and of the Spirit. Yet there is order: the Father is the principium of the Son and Spirit, and so the decree is “of the Father, through the Son, in the Spirit.” Agreement names the ordered concurrence of the persons in this one volitional act, not any alignment of divergent volitions.

- **Eternal, not merely economic, personal orientation**  
  The pactum salutis language stresses that the Son’s mediatorial mission and obedience are not ad hoc, but grounded in the eternal life of God. The Son is eternally “for” the Father in filial obedience, and the Spirit is eternally “of” both as the bond of love. Speaking of agreement highlights that the economic roles (sending, sent, applying) express what is fitting to these eternal relations, without implying any change or new purpose in God.

- **Ground of the economy’s covenantal form**  
  Reformed theologians often use “covenant” here to secure the forensic, representative, and promissory character of Christ’s work: he stands as federal head, bound by stipulations and promises before the Father, in the Spirit. The pactum is therefore a theological construction: it is a way of describing how the one decree structures the economy in covenant form, with the Son as second Adam and surety, without reifying a literal pre-temporal contract inside God.

## Relation of the pactum salutis to the one, simple, eternal decree

The crucial point is architectural: the pactum salutis is not an additional divine act alongside the decree, nor a distinct layer of decree; it is an aspect or internal ordering of the one decree, viewed with particular focus on the Trinitarian roles in redemption.

- **Identity in being, distinction in conception**  
  There are not “two decrees” (a general decree and then a covenant of redemption). Rather:
  
    - In reality, there is one simple decree, identical with God’s eternal act of willing.
    - In our conception, we can view that one decree under different “aspects” or “logical moments”: decree in general, decree as electing in Christ, decree as covenantally ordering Christ’s mediatorial obedience and reward.

  The pactum salutis is this last aspect: the decree as configuring the Son to be covenant head and surety, with the Father as the one who entrusts a people to him and promises him a reward, and the Spirit as the applier of the accomplished redemption.

- **From decree to covenantal economy**  
  Within the single decree:
  
    - God wills that salvation be administered by covenants in history (works, grace).
    - God wills that this historical covenant of grace rest upon a prior, foundational ordering: the Son’s mediatorial obedience and satisfaction as surety.  

  The pactum salutis therefore names the way the one decree structures the economic outworking of salvation covenantally, with Christ’s work bearing covenantal conditions and promises before the Father.

- **Christ’s two wills and the pactum**  
  A further precision prevents confusion:  
  The one divine will decrees that the Son assume a human nature with a created human will. The **covenantal obedience** proper to the mediator is executed in that human will in time. Thus:
  
    - Ad intra, there is only the one divine will; no new volition arises when the Son “agrees” to obey.
    - Ad extra and in time, the incarnate Son’s human will submits in Gethsemane and on the cross, fulfilling the covenantal stipulations.  

  The pactum salutis, strictly speaking, refers to the eternal divine willing that grounds this economic obedience; the obedience itself occurs in created history.

- **Guarding against fragmentation**  
  To keep the pactum salutis within orthodoxy:
  
    - It must not be treated as a bargain struck among three separate consciousnesses.
    - It must be seen as nothing other than the one decree, considered specifically as trinitarianly ordered toward redemption and then expressed in the mediatorial economy.

In sum, “agreement” ad intra, when used of the covenant of redemption, is an accommodated way of speaking of the one, simple, eternal decree as personally appropriated and ordered among Father, Son, and Spirit toward the accomplishment of salvation, without any plurality of wills, temporal process, or contractual negotiation in God.

top_exam_questions.question: You say Reformed theology rejects ideas of subordination because there is one will in God. How do you distinguish eternal relations of origin, the taxis among the persons, and the incarnate Son’s obedience to the Father, and where exactly do you locate the error of EFS in light of will as a property of nature, not person?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal framework: will, person, and nature in God

Classical Reformed trinitarianism receives the catholic axiom that **will follows nature, not person**:

- The divine essence is simple, undivided, and numerically one.
- All essential attributes, including intellect and will, are identical with that one essence.
- Therefore, the three hypostases do not each possess a distinct faculty of will; rather, the one divine will is personally subsistent and exercised in three irreducible modes.

This has two immediate consequences:

- Any talk of “the Father’s will” versus “the Son’s will” in God must be understood as a **personal mode of one will**, not separate volitional centers.
- Any subordination in “will” within the immanent Trinity, if taken strictly, implies either three divine natures, or a hierarchy within the one nature, both of which contradict Nicene and Reformed confessions.

Within that framework we must sharply distinguish: relations of origin, taxis, and the incarnate Son’s obedience.

## Eternal relations of origin

**Eternal generation** and **spiration** are ontological, not functional, differentiations:

- The Father is **unbegotten**, the Son **begotten of the Father**, the Spirit **proceeds from the Father and the Son**.
- These are **relations of origin**: they state how the persons are eternally, not what “roles” they voluntarily assume in time.

Several points matter for the EFS debate:

- These relations are **not acts of will** by which God decides to arrange an authority-structure; rather, they are intrinsic, necessary, and eternal.
- They are **asymmetrical relations** (the Father is not begotten by the Son), but this asymmetry is not a hierarchy of greater/lesser will, power, or authority.
- They ground **personal properties** (paternity, filiation, procession) but do not introduce gradations in the one divine essence.

Thus “from the Father” is a statement about **origin**, not about the Son living under a higher divine command.

## Taxis among the persons

By **taxis** (order), the tradition means the order of persons and of their inseparable operations:

- There is a **hypostatic order**: from the Father, through the Son, in the Spirit.
- There is a corresponding **order of operation**: external works are undivided, yet they exhibit a fitting pattern that reflects origin (e.g., the Father sends, the Son is sent, the Spirit is sent by Father and Son).

Key distinctions:

- Taxis is an order of **manifestation and appropriation**, not of authority-ranking.
- To say “the Father sends the Son” is to say the one divine will is enacted in a way **fitting** to paternity and filiation, not that the Father imposes a will that the Son might have declined.
- The missions of Son and Spirit **reveal** the eternal relations of origin; they do not introduce new structures of command and obedience into the Godhead.

Therefore, taxis gives us an ordered pattern of acting without positing **subordination in the one will**.

## The incarnate Son’s obedience

The obedience of Christ is located **hypostatically in the person of the Son**, but exercised **according to the assumed human nature**:

- In the incarnation the eternal Son assumes a complete human nature, including a created human will.
- The council of Chalcedon and subsequent dyothelite teaching insist: there are **two wills in Christ**, divine and human, united in the one person without confusion or division.
- Christ’s obedience—submitting to the Father’s will, learning obedience, not doing his own will—is obedience **according to his human will**, perfectly conforming to the divine will he shares with the Father and the Spirit.

This allows us to say:

- The Son is eternally equal in authority as God, yet **economically subordinate as man**, in his mediatorial office.
- Any language of the Son “obeying” the Father’s will can be properly predicated only of his **creaturely volitional act**, not of an eternal subjection of one divine will to another.

Consequently, obedience is a category of the **economy and of the human nature**, not of the eternal divine relations as such.

## Locating the error of EFS

With these distinctions in place, the error of Eternal Functional Subordination (in its stronger forms) can be located quite precisely.

First, EFS typically **re-describes ontological relations as authority-structures**:

- Eternal generation and paternity/filiation are treated as grounding an eternal command–obedience pattern, rather than as pure relations of origin.
- The Father’s being “head” of the Son is interpreted as a standing relationship of **authority and submission**, not merely as arche and taxis.

This imports a **monarchical hierarchy** into the Godhead that goes beyond the traditional doctrine of monarchy of the Father as principle of origin, and tends practically to undermine consubstantial equality.

Second, EFS tends, implicitly or explicitly, to **personalize the will**:

- When EFS theologians speak of the Father “having authority to command” and the Son “submitting his will,” they often suggest distinct volitional stances within the immanent Trinity.
- Even when they deny three ontological wills, their language trades on the intuition of **three functional wills** relating as superior and subordinate, which cannot be squared with the simplicity of the divine volition.

On Reformed and catholic principles, if there is one simple divine will identical with the essence, then:

- There is no room for the **possibility of disagreement** between persons; hence “submission” cannot mean a potential divergence resolved by acquiescence.
- Any “eternal submission” of the Son would either be a submission of God to God (which collapses into a metaphor for taxis) or it would smuggle in a creaturely modality into the immanent life of God.

Third, EFS blurs the **economy/immanence boundary**:

- It reads the incarnate Son’s human obedience back into the eternal Trinity as a timeless pattern of authority and submission.
- This confuses the economic mission (where true obedience is present in Christ’s human will) with the eternal processions (where no such obedience is possible or needed).

Orthodox Reformed theology insists:

- Eternal relations: **origin without subordination**.
- Taxis: **order without hierarchy of will**.
- Incarnate obedience: **real subordination according to the human nature**, not constitutive of the immanent Trinity.

In light of will as a property of nature, not person, the specific error of EFS lies in construing the eternal trinitarian distinctions as entailing a **hierarchy of authority and submission within the one divine will**, thereby mislocating what properly belongs to the incarnate economy of salvation into the inner life of the simple, consubstantial Trinity.

In light of will as a property of nature, not person, the specific error of EFS lies in construing the eternal trinitarian distinctions as entailing a hierarchy of authority and submission within the one divine will, thereby mislocating what properly belongs to the incarnate economy of salvation into the inner life of the simple, consubstantial Trinity.

top_exam_questions.question: Explain how the incarnate Son’s real obedience and submission to the Father are grounded in his human will while maintaining one divine will. How do you avoid both Nestorianism and monothelitism in this account?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal framework

Chalcedonian and post‑Chalcedonian Christology supply the categories needed.

- The incarnate Son is **one person (hypostasis)**, the eternal Logos.
- He subsists in **two natures**, divine and human, “without confusion, change, division, or separation.”
- Each nature possesses its **proper natural powers**: intellect, will, energy, etc.
- The subject of all Christ’s acts (willing, obeying, suffering, rising) is **the one person**, not two acting subjects.

Later, dyothelite (Maximus, Constantinople III) refinement adds:

- There are in Christ **two wills** (theandric dyothelitism), divine and human, because will follows nature.
- These are not two personal subjects but two **natural wills** in one hypostasis.
- The human will is not opposed to the divine will but is **freely and harmoniously “moved” and perfected** by the divine.

Classic Reformed theology receives this framework: one divine will in the Godhead; in the incarnate Son, a real human will is assumed without change to the divine.

## Grounding Christ’s obedience in his human will

The New Testament speaks of Christ’s obedience, submission, and learning (Heb 5:8; Phil 2:8; Lk 22:42). These cannot be predicated of the divine nature as such, but of the person **according to the human nature**.

- **First**, in virtue of the incarnation, the Logos assumes a complete human nature: body, rational soul, human intellect, and human will. If he lacks a human will, he is not consubstantial with us and cannot obey as the second Adam.
- **Second**, every act of obedience, prayer, growth, and suffering belongs to the **human will and affections of Christ**, truly and properly:
    - When he says, “not my will, but yours be done,” there is a genuine human volitional motion, capable in itself of natural shrinking from suffering, which is freely subordinated to the Father’s will.
    - When he “became obedient unto death,” he does so as man, actively willing, consenting, and persevering in obedience through his human will.
- **Third**, the divine will is not passive in this. The Logos is the *personal subject* of the human obedience:
    - It is the **person of the Son** who wills humanly, using his human will as the organ of obedient response.
    - The human will is **energized, preserved, and infallibly ordered** by the divine will; yet its acts are truly human, rational, and free, not mechanical or coerced.

Thus, the obedience and submission are **real human volitional acts**, yet they are the obedience of the **divine person** who eternally shares the one divine will with the Father and Spirit.

## Maintaining one divine will

Within Trinitarian doctrine:

- Will is a **property of nature**, not of person; therefore, the three persons share **one divine will**.
- Any notion of the Son’s “eternal functional subordination” as if he possessed a distinct personal divine will is excluded.
- The Son’s eternal relation to the Father is not a relation of superior and inferior wills, but of **eternal generation and consubstantiality**; the one simple divine will is identically the will of Father, Son, and Spirit.

In the economy, the Son’s incarnate mission and obedience express, in time and in a human mode, the **single, undivided divine volition** to redeem:

- The decree that the Son become incarnate, obey, and die is the **one divine decree**.
- The Son’s human obedience is the **temporal execution** of what the triune God eternally wills; it does not introduce a second or divergent divine volition.

So we affirm simultaneously:

- One divine will in the Godhead.
- A true human will in Christ, by which he actually obeys.

## Avoiding Nestorianism

Nestorianism arises if Christ’s distinct natures are so divided that there are effectively **two acting subjects**, the “man Jesus” and the divine Logos, loosely conjoined.

To avoid this:

- We insist that the **subject of the human will** is the **eternal Son** himself, not a separate human person.
- Every human volitional act—fear, shrinking, obedience, trust—is predicated of the **one person**:
    - “The Son obeys,” “God the Son prays,” “the Lord learns obedience,” all according to the human nature.
- The distinction of wills (divine and human) does not amount to a distinction of persons:
    - Just as there are two natures but one hypostasis, there are two natural wills but one hypostatic “who.”
    - The human will has no independent personal center; it subsists in the person of the Son.

Thus, the real human obedience does not create a second “I” alongside the Logos; rather, it is the mode in which this one “I” obeys as man.

## Avoiding monothelitism

Monothelitism denies a human will in Christ, asserting a single will in order to protect unity of person. This undercuts both soteriology and the reality of obedience.

To avoid this:

- We maintain that **what is not assumed is not healed**: if Christ lacks a human will, fallen human willing is not redeemed.
- Texts depicting internal struggle or submission (“not my will but yours”) are taken seriously as indicating:
    - A **created, finite, passible human will**, capable of natural aversion to suffering.
    - A genuine act of **free, moral submission** to God’s will.
- This human will is:
    - Never contrary in sinful rebellion to the divine will.
    - Nevertheless, genuinely distinct, undergoing real choices, temptations, and growth in experiential obedience.

Dyothelitism here is not an optional refinement but essential to explaining how Christ’s obedience is both truly human and redemptive, while his divine will remains impassible and immutable.

## Synthesis

The incarnate Son’s obedience and submission to the Father are the free, rational acts of his **true human will**, personally owned and activated by the eternal Logos, perfectly harmonized with the one divine will, such that we affirm two natural wills in one person and thereby avoid both the dual-subject error of Nestorianism and the denial of Christ’s human willing in monothelitism.

top_exam_questions.question: Define divine concurrence carefully and show how, in Reformed theology, it supports effectual calling and irresistible grace without making God the author of sin. How does this fit with a compatibilist account of human responsibility under an unchangeable decree?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal definition: divine concurrence

Divine concurrence, in classic Reformed usage, is the doctrine that God as first cause efficaciously concurs with, sustains, and directs all secondary causes in their operations, such that no event falls outside his providential government, yet secondary causes are real, distinct, and operate according to their own natures.

It involves three tightly related claims:

- **Conservation.** God upholds all things in being at every moment; nothing continues to exist or act independently of his conserving will.
- **Concurrence in every act.** In every action of a creature, there is one act with a twofold causal line: God as primary cause and the creature as secondary cause. God gives the act its existence; the creature specifies the mode and moral quality of the act in accord with its nature.
- **Governing concurrence.** God’s concurrence is not bare cooperation but purposive governance: he infallibly orders all events to the end fixed in his eternal decree.

Negatively, Reformed theology denies both:

- **Occasionalism,** which swallows up secondary causes into divine causality.
- **Semi-deism,** which lets secondary causes operate outside of or beyond God’s specific concurrence.

## Concurrence, effectual calling, and irresistible grace

Effectual calling and irresistible grace are special applications of concurrence in the ordo salutis.

### Effectual calling

Effectual calling is God’s act, by his Word and Spirit, of summoning the elect out of spiritual death into union with Christ in such a way that the call certainly results in their coming.

Divine concurrence structures this as follows:

- God uses created means (preaching, sacraments, providential circumstances) as **secondary causes** that truly address mind and will.
- Simultaneously, God the Spirit works as **primary cause** in the heart, illumining the mind, removing the heart of stone, and inclining the will to Christ.
- There is one composite “turning to Christ” in which:
    - as to being and efficacy, it is from God’s concurring grace;
    - as to personal appropriation, it is truly the sinner’s own act of believing and repenting.

Thus the call is “effectual” because the same God who externally calls by the Word concurrently, internally and sovereignly, produces the response.

### Irresistible (or invincible) grace

“Irresistible” does not mean the will is coerced, but that God’s renewing operation infallibly results in a free embrace of Christ.

Under concurrence:

- Grace is **efficacious**, not merely cooperative: God does not wait upon a neutral will but, by concurring as recreating cause, changes the will’s disposition.
- Once renewed, the will acts according to its new nature; it is moved sweetly and powerfully, not mechanically or violently.
- The certainty of the effect (conversion) derives from God’s decree and concurring operation, not from any independent self-determination in the sinner.

So concurrence underwrites effectual calling and irresistible grace by ensuring that God is not merely offering possibilities but actually bringing about the elect’s saving response through and in their own acts.

## Avoiding divine authorship of sin

The central worry is whether such pervasive divine causality makes God the author of sin. The Reformed answer depends on clear distinctions within concurrence and the decree.

### Distinctions in causality

Reformed theology distinguishes:

- **Efficient vs. deficient causality.**
    - Every act, as act (its “that-it-is”), has God as primary efficient cause.
    - The defect or disorder in a sinful act (its “that-it-is-evil”) arises from the disordered will of the creature, which, as fallen, inclines to wrong ends.
    - God concurs in the act’s existence and in the faculties acting; he does not infuse or approve the moral defect.
- **Will of decree vs. will of precept.**
    - By will of decree, God ordains that sinful acts occur as part of his providential plan (e.g., the crucifixion).
    - By will of precept, he commands righteousness and forbids the very sins he ordains to permit and govern.
    - The same event can be willed in different respects: God wills it as a justly permitted and overruled event; the sinner wills it as evil.

Thus, though God’s concurrence is necessary for the act to occur at all, the privation that constitutes sin as sin belongs solely to the creature’s disordered willing.

### Concurrence and permission

“Permission” in Reformed theology is not an indifferent non-action but a mode of governance:

- God **negatively** withholds certain restraining or renewing grace he was not obliged to give.
- He **positively** concurs in the natural act of the will and in all the circumstances, yet does not cause the evil intention.
- He sets the bounds and directs the outcome of sinful acts without sharing the sinful motive.

Therefore God is neither surprised by nor helpless before sin, yet he is not the moral author of it.

## Compatibilist responsibility under an unchangeable decree

Compatibilism maintains that human moral responsibility is compatible with divine determinism, provided that human actions arise from the agent’s own character and desires, without external compulsion.

### Unchangeable decree and free agency

Reformed theology affirms:

- God’s decree is eternal, comprehensive, and unchangeable.
- Yet the decree does not impose a foreign necessity upon events; it establishes that each event occurs by means congruent with the nature of its secondary causes.

With respect to human agents:

- They act **voluntarily**, according to what they most want in the circumstances.
- Their desires are indeed encompassed within God’s decree, but at the level of phenomenology and moral evaluation, they are not coerced: they choose what they love.
- Necessity here is **conditional** or **hypothetical**: given God’s decree and the actual state of the agent’s character and circumstances, the action will certainly occur; but the action proceeds from the agent’s own will.

Compatibilist responsibility follows:

- Responsibility tracks the source of the action in the agent’s settled dispositions and intentions, not in an indeterminate power to do otherwise under the same total conditions.
- Divine concurrence ensures that the act is not metaphysically independent of God, but it does not eliminate the fact that:
    - the sinner sins because he wants to;
    - the believer believes because, having been renewed, he wants to.

### Fitting this with grace and sin

In salvation:

- Irresistible grace is the Spirit’s concurring, renewing work that changes what the sinner wants; once renewed, the sinner’s faith is a responsible, voluntary act.
- The certainty of faith flows from decree and concurrence; the moral ownership of faith lies in the regenerate person who truly trusts.

In sin:

- Sinful acts are included in the decree and sustained by concurrence as acts.
- The moral evil is wholly from the corrupt will; the individual is fully responsible because he acts out of his own desires, without compulsion, even though God has decreed and concurs with the act’s existence and governs its outcome.

Thus divine concurrence grounds effectual calling and irresistible grace, fits coherently with an unchangeable decree, and—when combined with the act/defect distinction and the decretive/preceptive distinction—supports a robust compatibilist account of human responsibility without making God the author of sin.

top_exam_questions.question: You framed the issue as ‘salvation through faith alone, or free will.’ How does Reformed theology affirm both sola fide and a real, though non-libertarian, human willing? Define faith as the sole instrument of justification and distinguish it from the ground and cause of justification.
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal clarifications

Reformed theology refuses the disjunction “salvation through faith alone, or free will” by distinguishing several things that must not be conflated:

- The **ground** of justification.
- The **efficient cause** (principal actor) in justification.
- The **instrument** by which justification is received.
- The **mode** of human willing (compatibilist, not libertarian).

### Ground and cause of justification

In classic Reformed theology:

- The **ground** (or merit) of justification is **Christ alone**: his obedient life and atoning death, imputed to the sinner. Nothing in the sinner—neither faith, nor repentance, nor love—constitutes any part of the righteousness on account of which God declares the sinner righteous.

- The **efficient cause** of justification is **God alone**, specifically the triune God acting through the Father’s decree, the Son’s finished work, and the Spirit’s application. God justifies “the ungodly” by a judicial act, not by assisting them to produce a righteousness of their own.

Faith therefore cannot be the ground or cause of justification without displacing Christ or making God’s forensic act contingent on an intrinsic quality in us. To say that we are justified “because of” faith in the same sense we are justified “because of” Christ is to collapse the Creator–creature distinction and to reintroduce merit under another name.

### Faith as sole instrument

Faith is instead the **alone instrument** of justification:

- **Nature of faith.** Faith, in justification, is not a meritorious work but a receptive act:
  
    - It involves **knowledge** of Christ and his promise.
    - **Assent** to that testimony as true.
    - **Trust** (fiducia), a personal reliance on Christ as offered in the gospel.

- **Instrumental causality.** As instrument, faith:
  
    - Does not add anything to Christ’s righteousness.
    - Does not move God to become gracious.
    - Is simply the Spirit-enabled empty hand that receives and rests upon Christ and his righteousness.

Thus Reformed theology can say both “faith alone justifies” and “faith never exists alone,” because faith is intrinsically oriented to Christ (instrumental) and is inseparably accompanied, in regeneration, by other graces (sanctificatory fruits), which are excluded from the justifying act itself.

## Human willing: real but non-libertarian

Reformed theology denies **libertarian freedom** (the claim that a will act is free only if, under identical conditions, the agent could have done otherwise in a way not determined by God’s decree or character). Yet it robustly affirms that salvation involves **real human willing**.

Key distinctions:

- **Compatibilist freedom.** An act is free when it proceeds from the agent’s own will—desire, judgment, and choice—without external coercion. Determination by God’s decree and concurrence is compatible with genuine agency, responsibility, and voluntariness.

- **Bondage of the will in sin.** By nature, the will is not metaphysically inactive, but **morally unable** to choose God: it freely and stubbornly prefers darkness. This is a positive willing of sin, not an absence of willing.

- **Effectual calling and regeneration.** The Spirit renews the heart so that the sinner:
  
    - Receives a new disposition.
    - Sees Christ as desirable and true.
    - Freely comes to Christ in faith.

No one is dragged into faith; rather, the heart is so changed that believing becomes the most “natural” expression of the renewed will. The decree and effectual grace guarantee the result, but the believing itself is a genuine act of the person.

## Integrating sola fide with real human willing

The integration rests on several affirmations:

- Faith is a **real human act**—a movement of mind, will, and affections—yet it is also a **gift** and effect of grace.
- The same Spirit who unites us to Christ also elicits our faith; union with Christ and the act of believing are coincident from the standpoint of application, though logically the efficacy lies wholly in Christ, not in the quality of faith.
- Because faith is purely instrumental, its being **God-caused** does not make it a divine substitute for human agency; rather, it restores and elevates human agency so that we truly will what God efficaciously brings about.

Thus Reformed theology preserves **sola fide** by insisting that only the righteousness of Christ is the ground and only faith is the instrument, while simultaneously insisting that this faith is a genuine, non-coerced, Spirit-liberated human willing.

Faith therefore cannot be the ground or cause of justification without displacing Christ or making God’s forensic act contingent on an intrinsic quality in us. To say that we are justified “because of” faith in the same sense we are justified “because of” Christ is to collapse the Creator–creature distinction and to reintroduce merit under another name.

Faith as sole instrument

Faith is instead the alone instrument of justification:

  • Nature of faith. Faith, in justification, is not a meritorious work but a receptive act:

    • It involves knowledge of Christ and his promise.
    • Assent to that testimony as true.
    • Trust (fiducia), a personal reliance on Christ as offered in the gospel.

  • Instrumental causality. As instrument, faith:

    • Does not add anything to Christ’s righteousness.
    • Does not move God to become gracious.
    • Is simply the Spirit-enabled empty hand that receives and rests upon Christ and his righteousness.

Thus Reformed theology can say both “faith alone justifies” and “faith never exists alone,” because faith is intrinsically oriented to Christ (instrumental) and is inseparably accompanied, in regeneration, by other graces (sanctificatory fruits), which are excluded from the justifying act itself.

Human willing: real but non-libertarian

Reformed theology denies libertarian freedom (the claim that a will act is free only if, under identical conditions, the agent could have done otherwise in a way not determined by God’s decree or character). Yet it robustly affirms that salvation involves real human willing.

Key distinctions:

  • Compatibilist freedom. An act is free when it proceeds from the agent’s own will—desire, judgment, and choice—without external coercion. Determination by God’s decree and concurrence is compatible with genuine agency, responsibility, and voluntariness.

  • Bondage of the will in sin. By nature, the will is not metaphysically inactive, but morally unable to choose God: it freely and stubbornly prefers darkness. This is a positive willing of sin, not an absence of willing.

  • Effectual calling and regeneration. The Spirit renews the heart so that the sinner:

    • Receives a new disposition.
    • Sees Christ as desirable and true.
    • Freely comes to Christ in faith.

No one is dragged into faith; rather, the heart is so changed that believing becomes the most “natural” expression of the renewed will. The decree and effectual grace guarantee the result, but the believing itself is a genuine act of the person.

Integrating sola fide with real human willing

The integration rests on several affirmations:

  • Faith is a real human act—a movement of mind, will, and affections—yet it is also a gift and effect of grace.
  • The same Spirit who unites us to Christ also elicits our faith; union with Christ and the act of believing are coincident from the standpoint of application, though logically the efficacy lies wholly in Christ, not in the quality of faith.
  • Because faith is purely instrumental, its being God-caused does not make it a divine substitute for human agency; rather, it restores and elevates human agency so that we truly will what God efficaciously brings about.

Thus Reformed theology preserves sola fide by insisting that only the righteousness of Christ is the ground and only faith is the instrument, while simultaneously insisting that this faith is a genuine, non-coerced, Spirit-liberated human willing.

logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the Issue

The problem is that the earlier account moved too quickly from the claim that God has one will to the conclusion that “Reformed theology rejects ideas of subordination,” without carefully distinguishing:

- the **eternal relations of origin** in the immanent Trinity (begetting and procession),  
- legitimate **economic subordination** of the incarnate Son and mission of the Spirit in salvation history, and  
- the **illegitimate claim** of an eternal hierarchical ordering of authority and obedience within the Trinity (as in some “Eternal Functional Subordination” proposals).

As a result, it risked conflating different senses of “subordination” and did not clearly show how classic Reformed trinitarianism undergirds its soteriology.

## Doctrinal Clarifications

### One Essence, One Will, Distinct Personal Properties

Classic Reformed theology, following catholic orthodoxy, affirms:

- **One simple divine essence**: God is numerically one in being, power, and will. Will, in God, is a property of the divine nature, not of three discrete “centers” of consciousness.
- **Three distinct persons**: The Father is unbegotten, the Son is eternally begotten of the Father, and the Spirit eternally proceeds from the Father and the Son. These are **relations of origin**, not degrees of deity or rank.
- **No ontological subordination**: Because each person is the whole, undivided God, there can be no inferiority of essence, glory, or authority within the immanent Trinity.

The single divine will is personally subsistent in three hypostases, but not divided into three separate volitional faculties that could be ranked in authority.

### Eternal Relations vs. Economic Missions

The Reformed tradition rigorously distinguishes:

- **Immanent Trinity (ad intra)**:  
  - The Son’s eternal generation and the Spirit’s procession are modes of subsisting, not modes of obeying or commanding.  
  - There is order (taxis) among the persons—Father as “of none,” Son “of the Father,” Spirit “of the Father and of the Son”—without gradation of authority.

- **Economic Trinity (ad extra)**:  
  - The persons act inseparably in all external works, yet with a fitting order of origin reflected in missions: the Father sends the Son; the Father and the Son send the Spirit.  
  - In the history of salvation, the incarnate Son assumes the form of a servant, obeys the Father according to his human will, and the Spirit is poured out as the gift of the exalted Christ.

This **obedience** belongs to the Son as man (and as Mediator) in the economy, not as a lesser divine person in eternity.

### Legitimate and Illegitimate “Subordination”

From a Reformed confessional standpoint:

- **Affirmed subordination (economic, incarnational):**
  - The Son, according to his human nature and mediatorial office, is obedient to the Father, fulfills the Father’s will, and receives a kingdom.
  - The Spirit is “sent” and “proceeds” in the economy to apply redemption, acting in a role that is “after” Christ’s in the order of salvation history.

- **Denied subordination (ontological or eternal-hierarchical):**
  - There is no eternal relation of authority and obedience between Father and Son understood as different ranks within the Godhead.
  - The Son and the Spirit are not subordinated in will or authority as God; to posit an eternal, asymmetrical authority structure in God is to imply three distinct divine wills or a gradation within one will, which contradicts simplicity and consubstantiality.

Thus the Reformed rejection is not of all “subordination” language, but of any claim that the Son and Spirit are eternally under the Father’s authority in a way that implies inequality or multiple wills.

## Soteriological Implications

This trinitarian clarity is directly connected to the doctrine of salvation:

- **Covenant of redemption (pactum salutis)**:
  - The pactum describes the eternal, harmonious counsel of the triune God concerning redemption, not a contract negotiated between independent divine agents.  
  - It presupposes one decree of the one God, personally appropriated: the Father choosing, the Son undertaking to redeem, the Spirit undertaking to apply.

- **Obedience of Christ**:
  - The Son’s obedience that secures salvation is the obedience of the incarnate Mediator, according to his human will, grounded in his eternal person as Son.  
  - This obedience does not reflect an eternal subordination in the Godhead, but the voluntary condescension of the Son who, being “in the form of God,” takes “the form of a servant.”

- **Unity of divine action**:
  - Because there is one will and one decree, the Father’s electing, the Son’s redeeming, and the Spirit’s applying are not competing or hierarchically ordered divine projects, but the one undivided work of the triune God ad extra.

In classic Reformed theology, therefore, eternal relations of origin and economic roles are carefully distinguished so that the Son’s and Spirit’s economic “subordination” in salvation history does not entail any ontological or eternal subordination within the Trinity itself.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

In the written essay, the relation between faith and free will was posed as if one had to choose: either salvation is through faith alone, or humans have free will. That framing implies that affirming sola fide is in tension with affirming a real human will. Classic Reformed theology, however, denies that alternative: it simultaneously affirms justification by faith alone and a robust, though non-libertarian, account of human willing, governed by God’s decree and grace. The missing piece is a clear compatibilist account of human freedom in relation to God’s sovereignty and saving grace.

## Doctrinal analysis

### Sola fide and its locus

In Reformed theology, **salvation** can be used broadly or narrowly.

- In the narrow sense, **justification** is by faith alone: God pardons sins and imputes Christ’s righteousness to the ungodly who receive and rest upon Christ by faith, not by works, merit, or any cooperative contribution.
- Faith itself is:
  - the sole **instrument** of justification;
  - a **gift of God** worked by the Spirit through the Word;
  - an act that the renewed person truly and voluntarily performs.

Thus, sola fide denies that anything besides faith is the instrument of justification; it does not deny that in coming to faith the human agent really wills and acts.

### Reformed compatibilist freedom

Reformed theology rejects **libertarian freedom** (the power of contrary choice independent of God’s determining will) but affirms a **compatibilist** freedom.

- A human choice is free when:
  - it proceeds from the agent’s own mind, affections, and will;
  - it is not coerced or externally compelled contrary to the agent’s prevailing desires.
- God’s eternal decree and providence infallibly determine what choices occur, yet:
  - secondary causes (including human wills) are real causes;
  - the moral character of the act derives from the nature and intention of the human agent.

In the state of sin, the will is in **bondage** with respect to spiritual good: it is free in the compatibilist sense, but enslaved in its moral inclination. In the state of grace, the regenerate will is **liberated** and renewed so that it now freely chooses Christ.

### Grace, faith, and the will

Within this framework:

- The call of the gospel is addressed to human hearers who are commanded to repent and believe; these are genuine acts of will, not mere appearances.
- In effectual calling and regeneration, the Spirit:
  - renews the heart, illumines the mind, and changes the disposition;
  - thereby makes the sinner “willing in the day of God’s power.”
- Once renewed, the person truly and spontaneously believes:
  - Faith is not God believing instead of us; it is we who believe.
  - Yet this believing is wholly due to God’s prior gracious work; without regeneration, the will would never choose Christ.

So the Reformed position is not: either salvation is by faith alone or humans have free will. Rather: salvation is by grace alone through faith alone, and this faith is the real, free (compatibilist) exercise of a will renewed by sovereign grace.

## Evaluation

From a classic Reformed standpoint, there is no antithesis between sola fide and human willing; instead, God’s sovereign, effectual grace establishes the very conditions under which the human will truly and freely believes unto salvation.

logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The earlier treatment of Molinism asserted that because Molinism posits a “middle knowledge” logically prior to God’s decree, this jeopardizes the certainty of the divine decree. However, it did not show why mere logical priority of knowledge to decree entails any real threat to metaphysical certainty; it left the charge at the level of assertion rather than argument. The task is to explain, from a Reformed confessional standpoint, how Molinist middle knowledge, as actually construed, compromises the sovereignty and certainty of God’s decree.

## Doctrinal analysis

From a classic Reformed perspective (as in the confessions), the basic structure is:

- God’s **knowledge** is identical with his simple, eternal being.
- God’s **decree** is a single, all-encompassing, eternal act of will, not temporally but logically prior to all created realities.
- What shall come to pass is certain because it is determined by God’s decree; creatures are real causes, but their reality and causal efficacy depend entirely on this prior decree.

In this framework, epistemic order and volitional order in God are not genuinely separable stages; talk of “prior” and “posterior” is only a logical ordering within the one simple act of God.

### Molinism’s structure

Molinism introduces a tri-fold logical ordering:

- **Natural knowledge**: God’s knowledge of necessary truths (possibilities, essences).
- **Middle knowledge**: God’s knowledge of counterfactuals of libertarianly free creaturely acts (“If person S were in circumstance C, S would freely do A and not B.”).
- **Free knowledge**: God’s knowledge of the actual world, consequent upon his decree to actualize some particular world.

Two points are crucial for critique:

- The counterfactuals known in middle knowledge are **contingent** truths about what libertarianly free creatures would do, and yet they are held to be:
  
    - true prior to any divine decree, and  
    - not determined by God’s will, but grounded in creaturely libertarian freedom.

- God’s decree is then said to select a world whose history fits these counterfactuals; his decree is constrained by what these counterfactuals already make possible.

The key Reformed objection is not to “logical priority” as such, but to the **source and independence** of those pre-decretal contingent truths.

## How this undermines metaphysical certainty and sovereignty

The Reformed concern can be stated in several connected theses.

### Dependence of the decree on independent contingent truths

On Molinism:

- The truth-values of counterfactuals of freedom are fixed prior (logically) to the decree and are not effects of God’s will or decree.
- For every feasible world God might actualize, the detailed patterns of creaturely free choices are already determined by these counterfactuals.

Therefore:

- God’s decree about which world to actualize is **conditioned by** a field of contingent truths he does not determine.
- This means that for many features of history (including, crucially, who will freely believe or persist in unbelief), God cannot, by decree alone, secure a different outcome without contradicting the already-given counterfactuals.

From a Reformed standpoint, metaphysical certainty should be grounded solely in God’s antecedent decree; on Molinism, a large class of contingent truths is instead ontologically independent, and God’s decree becomes selective and coordinative with respect to them, not determinative of them.

### Threat to the absoluteness of the decree

On classic Reformed teaching:

- God’s decree is **most wise, free, and absolute**; all that comes to pass, including the contingent free acts of creatures, is comprehended in and rendered certain by that decree.
- Creatures are genuinely responsible, but their acts are encompassed by a concurrence grounded in the decree; there are no brute creaturely determinations standing outside of or above the decree.

By contrast, on Molinism:

- Certain crucial conditions of the decree’s content are already “fixed” by counterfactuals of freedom for which God is not the determining ground.
- God’s will, in its specifying role, confronts a network of libertarian outcomes that limit which worlds are “feasible.” For example, if it is a pre-decretal truth that “Were Peter placed in C, he would libertarianly deny Christ,” then God cannot decree a world where Peter is in C and yet freely does not deny Christ, without altering that counterfactual truth.

Thus, the decree’s freedom and absoluteness are curtailed:

- God can choose which persons to create and in what circumstances, but he cannot, by decree, ensure that any particular individual freely performs some action contrary to the given counterfactuals.
- In matters of salvation, this entails that God cannot, by sheer sovereign decree, render it certain that some individuals will freely come to faith if all “nearby” counterfactuals say they would libertarianly reject the gospel.

In Reformed terms, the decree is no longer the ultimate ground of the difference between the elect and the reprobate; that difference now depends, at a fundamental level, on counterfactuals of creaturely freedom not determined by God.

### Logical priority as signaling a deeper metaphysical issue

Logical priority, by itself, need not threaten certainty. The problem arises because, on Molinism:

- What is logically prior to the decree includes contingent facts that are neither necessary truths nor grounded in the divine nature or will.
- These logically prior facts are taken to be **brute** with respect to God: he finds them as true and works “with” them.

Thus the appeal to logical order is not mere bookkeeping. It encodes a claim about:

- which truths are dependent on God’s decree, and  
- which truths, though contingent, are not.

The Reformed contention is that introducing a class of contingent, pre-decretal truths with this independence is incompatible with:

- divine aseity in the domain of contingent reality, and  
- the confessional assertion that all things whatsoever come to pass are determined by the free and immutable decree of God.

Hence logical priority here does mark a metaphysical priority: it signals that the decree no longer stands as the sole, ultimate grounding of the full determinate history of the world, including the distribution and efficacy of grace.

## Evaluation

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, Molinism’s middle knowledge does not merely rearrange logical order; by positing pre-decretal, divinely ungrounded counterfactuals of libertarian freedom, it relocates the ultimate source of many contingent truths outside the divine decree, thereby compromising both the metaphysical certainty and the sovereign absoluteness of God’s purpose in salvation.

  • God’s will, in its specifying role, confronts a network of libertarian outcomes that limit which worlds are “feasible.” For example, if it is a pre-decretal truth that “Were Peter placed in C, he would libertarianly deny Christ,” then God cannot decree a world where Peter is in C and yet freely does not deny Christ, without altering that counterfactual truth.

Thus, the decree’s freedom and absoluteness are curtailed:

  • God can choose which persons to create and in what circumstances, but he cannot, by decree, ensure that any particular individual freely performs some action contrary to the given counterfactuals.
  • In matters of salvation, this entails that God cannot, by sheer sovereign decree, render it certain that some individuals will freely come to faith if all “nearby” counterfactuals say they would libertarianly reject the gospel.

In Reformed terms, the decree is no longer the ultimate ground of the difference between the elect and the reprobate; that difference now depends, at a fundamental level, on counterfactuals of creaturely freedom not determined by God.

Logical priority as signaling a deeper metaphysical issue

Logical priority, by itself, need not threaten certainty. The problem arises because, on Molinism:

  • What is logically prior to the decree includes contingent facts that are neither necessary truths nor grounded in the divine nature or will.
  • These logically prior facts are taken to be brute with respect to God: he finds them as true and works “with” them.

Thus the appeal to logical order is not mere bookkeeping. It encodes a claim about:

  • which truths are dependent on God’s decree, and
  • which truths, though contingent, are not.

The Reformed contention is that introducing a class of contingent, pre-decretal truths with this independence is incompatible with:

  • divine aseity in the domain of contingent reality, and
  • the confessional assertion that all things whatsoever come to pass are determined by the free and immutable decree of God.

Hence logical priority here does mark a metaphysical priority: it signals that the decree no longer stands as the sole, ultimate grounding of the full determinate history of the world, including the distribution and efficacy of grace.

Evaluation

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, Molinism’s middle knowledge does not merely rearrange logical order; by positing pre-decretal, divinely ungrounded counterfactuals of libertarian freedom, it relocates the ultimate source of many contingent truths outside the divine decree, thereby compromising both the metaphysical certainty and the sovereign absoluteness of God’s purpose in salvation.

In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/logic_weaknesses:

The discussion of Open Theism conflates denial of exhaustive definite foreknowledge with the claim that God "reacts" to human actions without analyzing Open Theist claims about divine planning, risk, and providence, resulting in a caricature rather than a reasoned refutation.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The weakness is that Open Theism was treated as if it simply says: “God does not know the future and therefore merely reacts to human actions,” without engaging its more nuanced claims about divine planning, providential governance, and God’s willingness to take “risk.” This produces a caricature rather than a substantive, Reformed critique.

## Positive exposition of Open Theism

To correct this, Open Theism must first be stated in its own terms.

Open Theists distinguish:

- **Exhaustive definite foreknowledge of future free acts**: They deny that God has this, not because of ignorance or limitation in power, but because such acts are said not yet to exist even as truths; God knows them as possibilities, not as settled certainties.
- **Divine planning and purpose**: God is said to have a real overarching plan (e.g., to redeem, to have a people, to defeat evil), but this plan is “flexible,” incorporating multiple possible pathways depending on genuinely undetermined creaturely choices.
- **Providence as dynamic governance**:
    - God acts in history, makes real commitments and promises, and responds to creaturely decisions.
    - God sometimes “takes risks”: He pursues aims that might not be realized in the way or to the extent he desires because human freedom can frustrate particular divine intentions.
- **Divine knowledge**:
    - God knows all that can be known: the exhaustive range of possibilities, all causal structures, and the actual past and present with exhaustive precision.
    - What he does not know, on this view, are future free contingents as settled truths; he knows them only as might-be’s.

Thus, Open Theism does not present God as merely “reactive” in the sense of having no forethought or plan; rather, it presents God as a wise, resourceful strategist who adapts in real time within an open future that he has chosen to create.

## Reformed confessional critique

From a classic Reformed standpoint, several points are decisive.

### Divine decree and exhaustive providence

The Reformed confessions teach:

- **A single, eternal, all-encompassing decree**: God “freely and unchangeably ordains whatsoever comes to pass.” This includes the free acts of creatures as truly contingent and voluntary, yet certainly coming to pass under his decree and providence.
- **Providence as execution of the decree**: God’s providence is not a flexible trial-and-error strategy within an open future, but the infallible outworking in time of an eternal, comprehensive purpose.

Open Theism rejects both the unchangeability and the exhaustive scope of this decree. Even if it affirms a general telos (e.g., God will triumph over evil), it treats many particular outcomes as unresolved, contingent not merely in their mode but in their existence, and thus not encompassed by a determinate divine counsel. This is incompatible with the Reformed doctrine of God’s decree and government.

### Divine knowledge and aseity

Reformed theology grounds God’s knowledge in his own being and decree:

- God knows all things, actual and possible, in and of himself; his knowledge does not arise from external reality disclosing itself to him over time.
- Future contingents are known with certainty because God has decreed them; their contingency is real at the level of secondary causation, but their occurrence is not “open” to God.

By contrast, Open Theism:

- Makes God’s knowledge in significant measure dependent on the unfolding history of creaturely choices.
- Introduces a real “epistemic risk” for God regarding future free actions: God may hope for outcome A, but B may occur instead; only as agents act does God definitively know which.

This conflicts with divine aseity and immutability as classically confessed. If God’s knowledge of the future is temporally perfected by new information from creatures, then God is not immutable in knowledge and is, in a real sense, conditioned by his creation.

### Divine will, risk, and sovereignty

Open Theism portrays God as taking genuine risks:

- Some of God’s intentions may be permanently frustrated by creaturely freedom (not merely his preceptive will, but aspects of his intended providential path).
- God can be “disappointed” in a non-anthropomorphic sense: outcomes he hoped for and aimed at fail to materialize.

The Reformed view distinguishes:

- **Decretive will**: What God will infallibly bring to pass; this cannot be frustrated.
- **Preceptive will**: What God commands and delights in as good; this is often violated.

From within this framework:

- God takes no metaphysical “risk” regarding the history of the world, for there is no possible outcome outside his decree.
- The language of “risk” collapses the distinction between his decretive and preceptive will, and subtly implies that God’s ultimate purposes are contingent on created choices.

Therefore, Open Theism’s account of risk and frustrated divine aims contradicts the Reformed confession of God’s absolute sovereignty and the certainty of his counsel.

### Responsiveness without Open Theism

Open Theists often argue that only their model preserves genuine divine–human relationality and biblical depictions of God responding, repenting, grieving, changing his course, and so forth.

Reformed theology answers by:

- Affirming that God truly responds in the economy of his works, yet
- Interpreting the biblical anthropopathisms and anthropomorphisms analogically:
    - God’s “change” is the temporal expression of an unchanging eternal decree.
    - God’s “repentance” signifies a change in his outward dealings, not an alteration in his eternal purpose or knowledge.

Thus, one does not need an open future for God to be personally engaged and interactive with his creatures; the dynamism lies in history, not in God’s being or knowledge.

## Conclusion

A fair account of Open Theism acknowledges its attempt to preserve a planning, risk-taking, responsive God within an open future, but from a classic Reformed standpoint this model fatally compromises God’s exhaustive decree, exhaustive definite foreknowledge, and immutable aseity, and so must be rejected as incompatible with the confessional doctrine of God and providence.

logic_weaknesses.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/logic_weaknesses:

The essay moves quickly from divine concurrence to the conclusion that this "highlights the unchangeable, irresistible nature of divine election and grace" without explaining how concurrence, as such, entails irresistibility, leaving a gap between premise and conclusion.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The problematic move is this: the essay states that divine concurrence – God as primary cause working in and through secondary causes – “highlights the unchangeable, irresistible nature of divine election and grace,” but it does not show why concurrence itself entails, or even implies, the irresistibility of saving grace. The reasoning slides from a general doctrine of God’s causal relation to the world to a specifically soteriological conclusion without showing the intermediate steps.

## Doctrinal clarification

Divine concurrence, in classic Reformed usage, is a doctrine about providence in general, not about election or regeneration in particular.

- **Concursus** means that every created act is simultaneously:
  - fully the act of a secondary cause (truly contingent, free, responsible), and  
  - sustained, premoved, and governed by God as the first cause.

- This applies to all events (good and evil), not only to saving events. By itself, concurrence establishes:
  - God’s universal causality and sovereignty over all creaturely acts.
  - The compatibility of divine sovereignty with real secondary causality.

Concurrence, as such, does not by itself yield **irresistible grace**. One could, in principle, affirm a robust concursus while holding that, in the soteriological sphere, God concurs in such a way that the human will remains able to finally resist his saving motions. That is essentially the “simultaneous concurrence” option some non-Reformed views take.

So the missing step is: why, in Reformed theology, does God’s concurring action in the event of faith and conversion have an irreversible, efficacious character?

## From concurrence to efficacious, irresistible grace

The connection arises not from concurrence considered abstractly, but from concurrence interpreted in light of:

- God’s eternal, unconditional decree of election.
- The nature of the ordo salutis, especially effectual calling and regeneration.
- The specific manner in which God moves the will in saving acts.

### Election and the specification of concurrence

Reformed theology begins with a comprehensive, particular decree:

- God not only decrees universals (“there shall be a redeemed people”) but also particulars (this person, at this time, by these means, shall be brought infallibly to faith).
- Providence, including concurrence, is the execution in time of that decree.

Therefore, when God concurs in the saving history of an elect individual, he is not concurring in a merely indeterminate way; his concurrence is ordered to the infallible fulfillment of a definite decretive intention: that this person come to Christ.

This means:

- In every movement toward conversion, God is not a neutral or merely permissive co-actor; he is actualizing exactly what he has eternally decreed shall come to pass.
- If the decree of election is unchangeable and efficacious, then the concurrence that executes it cannot terminate in failure; otherwise, God’s own decree would be frustrated by his own mode of concurring.

Thus, **immutability of the decree**, plus **universal concurrence**, together demand that the concurrence which realizes the decree in the elect be efficacious.

### Effectual calling and regeneration as a special mode of concurrence

Classic Reformed theology distinguishes between:

- **Common grace / general operations of the Spirit**, which can be and are often resisted.
- **Special, effectual grace**, by which God inwardly renews the heart and infallibly brings the elect to faith.

Both are modes of divine concursus, but they differ in **specification and intent**:

- In common operations, God concurs with the created faculties such that, while he truly moves and enables, he does not intend, in that act, to secure infallible conversion; the act is ordered to moral suasion, external call, restraint of sin, etc.
- In regenerating and effectually calling, God concurs as first cause in a way that:
  - changes the faculty (new heart, new birth), not merely assists it;
  - determines the act (coming to Christ) infallibly, though congruently with the renewed nature.

In other words, concurrence is the genus; **irresistible grace is a species of concurrence distinguished by its decretive goal (salvation of the elect) and its transformative mode (regeneration and effectual calling).**

### How this secures irresistibility while preserving freedom

Reformed theology then deploys its broader account of will and freedom:

- Freedom is not indifference or the power to act contrary to the strongest inclination; it is acting according to one’s prevailing disposition without external compulsion.
- In regeneration, God, through a special concursus, changes the disposition itself, so that:
  - the renewed will infallibly and freely chooses Christ;
  - resistance is not “overpowered” from outside, but dissolved from within by a new love and light.

Thus:

- Divine concurrence is always present.
- In the elect, that concurrence, specified by the decree and enacted as regeneration and effectual calling, is such that the creaturely act of believing is both:
  - truly free and voluntary, and  
  - certainly brought about, so that the grace that produces it is, in this sense, irresistible.

## Evaluation and correction of the original inference

The essay’s bare claim that “divine concurrence … highlights the unchangeable, irresistible nature of divine election and grace” omits the essential intermediate claims:

- Concurrence is the mode of execution of a specific, immutable decree of election.
- In saving acts, God’s concurring causality is not merely cooperative but renovating and determinative in accordance with that decree.
- The Reformed conception of freedom allows such determinative concurrence without destroying voluntariness.

With these premises supplied, one can say:

- Divine concurrence, when read through the Reformed doctrines of decree, regeneration, and effectual calling, implies that the grace given to the elect in conversion is efficacious and therefore cannot finally be resisted.

The relation is therefore not that concurrence in itself proves irresistibility, but that, in the Reformed system, the concurrence by which God executes his immutable decree in the elect necessarily takes the form of irresistible, effectual grace.
